bestBHT.bht: Babylon, representing Rome, proudly claims to be queen and denies any widowhood or sorrow. This arrogance is rooted in Rome's historical power and influence, which hindered the Jews' acceptance of Christianity. However, her self-glorification will result in torment and mourning as God brings judgment upon her. The punishment will be a proportional retribution for her sins. Rome's pride will be humbled, leaving her in desolation and darkness.

Henry Alford: In proportion as she glorified herself, and luxuriated, so much torment and grief give to her.
Because in her heart she saith [that] I sit a queen and am not a widow.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: I am seated (this long time) . . . I am no widow . . . I shall see no sorrow," marks her complete unconcerned security as to the past, present, and future [BENGEL].
Babylon is a former Rome, and Rome a latter Babylon. Rome is a daughter of Babylon, and by her, as by her mother, God has been pleased to subdue the world under one sway" [AUGUSTINE].
Romish idolatries have been the great stumbling-blocks to the Jews' acceptance of Christianity.
Albert Barnes: By as much as she has lived in luxury and dissoluteness, so let her suffer now.
I sit a queen - Indicative of pride, and of an asserted claim to rule.
In this state we may expect to find papal Rome, even when its last judgments are about to come upon it; in this state it has usually been; in this state it is now.
Marvin Vincent: I sit a queen and am no widow.
Philip Schaff: The humiliation of Babylon shall be the counterpart of her glorying.
That she says these things 'in her heart' can hardly be intended to exclude the idea of loud boastings.
She has found another husband and many lovers.
Archibald T. Robertson: So much give her of torment and mourning.
I sit a queen... and am no widow.
John Gill: And lived deliciously: in a very luxuriant manner, as the popes, cardinals, archbishops, bishops, priests, monks, and friars have done...
...stripping her of her fine clothes and rich apparel; and by taking away her fat benefices from her, which will cut her to the heart; and by burning her with fire, which will be very excruciating...

...though she fancies she shall be no widow, that is, bereft of people and power...yet ere long, like old Babylon, she will have no men in her, but will be inhabited by devils, foul spirits, and hateful birds.
John Wesley: So much torment give her — Proportioning the punishment to the sin.
I sit — Her usual style. Hence those expressions, 'The chair, the see of Rome: he sat so many years.'
And shall see no sorrow — From the death of my children, or any other calamity; for God himself will defend 'the church.'

bhtAttempts.bht: In Revelation 18:7, the verse describes the arrogance and self-assuredness of Babylon, specifically Rome, in proclaiming herself as a queen and not a widow, and in boasting about her luxurious lifestyle without ever experiencing sorrow. This prideful attitude reflects Rome's historical influence and the stumbling block it created for the acceptance of Christianity among the Jews. However, this self-glorification will ultimately lead to torment and mourning, as God will bring judgment upon her. The punishment will be proportionate to her sins, reflecting the principle of retribution. Despite her claims, Rome will be humbled and inhabited by darkness.

In her arrogance, Babylon, symbolizing Rome, exalts herself as a queen without ever experiencing sorrow. Her luxurious lifestyle and idolatrous practices have hindered the Jews from accepting Christianity. However, her boastful confidence will be met with torment and mourning as God brings judgment upon her. Just as she proudly declares herself a queen, Rome will be humbled and left desolate. The severity of her punishment will match the magnitude of her sins, demonstrating the principle of divine retribution.

Babylon, representing Rome, proudly boasts as a queen, dismissing any notion of widowhood or sorrow. This arrogance stems from her historical influence and the stumbling block it created for the Jews. However, her exaltation will lead to her downfall, as God will inflict torment and mourning upon her. The punishment will be proportional to her sin, reflecting the principle of retribution. Despite her claims, Rome will be left desolate, inhabited by darkness and spiritual corruption.

Babylon, symbolizing Rome, glorifies herself and lives luxuriously, proclaiming herself as a queen and denying any widowhood or sorrow. This self-assuredness reflects Rome's historical dominance and the challenge it posed to the acceptance of Christianity by the Jews. However, this arrogance will bring upon her torment and mourning, as God will execute judgment. The severity of her punishment will be a fitting retribution for her sins. Ultimately, Rome's pride will be humbled, and she will be left in desolation and darkness.

Babylon, representing Rome, proudly claims to be queen and denies any widowhood or sorrow. This arrogance is rooted in Rome's historical power and influence, which hindered the Jews' acceptance of Christianity. However, her self-glorification will result in torment and mourning as God brings judgment upon her. The punishment will be a proportional retribution for her sins. Rome's pride will be humbled, leaving her in desolation and darkness.
